WHAT IS HYDRAULIC FRACTURING? Hydraulic fracturing is a process of creating or restoring fractures in a geological formation using fluids and proppants to stimulate the production of oil and gas wells. According to Belyad et al. (2017), the fracture creation process involves pumping sand, water, and specific chemicals at high flow rates and pressure. This technique is typically applied to unconventional reservoirs to extract hydrocarbons. Hydraulic fracturing has been used with the purpose of increasing permeability and reducing formation damage caused during drilling and completion operations. Unconventional shale reservoirs are known for having extremely low permeabilities. In an attempt to maximize production from these reservoirs, hydraulic fracturing is performed in all wells, as without this technique, these reservoirs would never produce at economically viable rates. According to Belyad et al. (2017), hydraulic fracturing has other applications such as: 1. Increasing the production rate of low-permeability reservoirs, such as shale formations in general. 2. Increasing the surface area of formation contact with the wellbore. 3. Reducing the number of wells through horizontal hydraulic fracturing. 4. Connecting hydraulic fractures with naturally existing ones. 5. Enhancing the production rate of wells that were damaged during drilling operations. Source (Figure): Akhir (2020) #hydraulicfracturing #shalereservoirs #wellprodutivity #oilandgas #oilproduction #petroleumengineering

What is slug flow? According to Beggs (1991) slug flow is a type of multiphase flow pattern encountered in pipelines or conduits where both gas and liquid phases are present. In slug flow, the flow is characterized by the intermittent movement of large gas bubbles separated by liquid slugs. Why Production Engineers are always find a way to mitigate its occurrence? Slug flow can be particularly problematic in some cases, as it can lead to issues such as pressure surges, vibration, and increased wear and tear on equipment. How does it occur? For example, when the production flow rate is very low, the liquid accumulates at the lowest point of the riser (figure bellow). After the occurrence of the blockage, already at the second point, while the hydrostatic column of the liquid is greater than the upstream gas pressure of the blockage, there will be a continuous increase in this pressure caused by the compression of the produced gas. At the third point, when the gas manages to overcome the hydrostatic pressure generated by the liquid and reaches the base of the riser, there is a violent displacement of the slug due to the rapid expansion of the gas and reduction of the hydrostatic column. This phenomenon causes significant variations in the processing plant, complicating the separation processes and even potentially damaging equipment. Finally, after the accumulated liquid is removed, the process will repeat itself. Figure (source): Pickering et al,. (2001) #slugflow #multiphaseflow #multiphaseflowpattern #hidrodynamicinstabilities #oilproduction #productionengineering #petroleumengineering

O sector petrolífero é o principal impulsionador da economia angolana, pois é responsável pela maior fonte de receitas para o estado. Porém, ultimamente o sector tem enfrentado um declínio na produção. Segundo a Agência Nacional de Petróleos, Gás e Biocombustíveis (ANPG) as principais causas do declínio da produção são: Queda do preço do barril de petróleo; Baixa conversão dos recursos em reservas; Irregularidade na realização de novas licitações de concessões petrolíferas; Morosidade na aprovação dos contratos nas concessões petrolíferas; Novas descobertas com pequenas acumulações; Degradação das instalações, Desempenho dos campos/reservatórios; Inexistência de políticas de incentivos para o desenvolvimento de campos marginais; Falta de uma política de gás natural de modo a permitir a monetização deste produto. Como parte das suas estratégias para reverter este cenário e criar novas oportunidades de investimentos no sector petrolífero, o governo angolano efectuou reformas legais de reestruturação no sector. Uma destas reformas tem a ver com a adequação dos termos fiscais e contratuais aos campos marginais, descrita no decreto presidencial 6/18. Os incentivos fiscais compreendem: i. As taxas de imposto de Produção de Petróleo e de Imposto sobre o Rendimento de Petróleo (IRP), bem com a taxa de prémio de investimento para efeitos de IRP e de bónus de Produção, são fixadas com base no volume de recursos recuperáveis; ii. Os encargos capitalizáveis podem ser amortizados por um período entre 2 e 4 anos de acordo com o volume de recursos recuperáveis; iii. A liquidação de IRP apenas é exigível no 3.º, 4.º ou 5.º ano de amortização dos encargos capitalizáveis; iv. As despesas de desenvolvimento são recuperadas entre 2 e 4 anos, de acordo com volume de recursos recuperáveis; v. Isenção total dos encargos e direitos aduaneiros sobre a exportação de petróleo por um período de 5 anos a contar do início da produção comercial. Essa medida, tem impulsionado imenso o desenvolvimento de campos marginais em Angola, dentre eles, o CLOV fase 2 da petrolífera francesa Total Energies.
